meanings.definition: (verb) to turn the pages of a book or magazine quickly
meanings.sent1: She leafed through the magazine to find the article she wanted to read.
meanings.sent2: He leafed through the pages of the novel, eager to know how the story ended.
meanings.sent3: The librarian leafed through the book so fast, it looked like a blur of pages.
meanings.sent4: As she leafed through the cookbook, the recipes seemed to dance before her eyes.
meanings.sent5: The student leafed through the textbook, trying to absorb as much information as possible.

meanings.sent1: The tree in the park was tall and leafed, providing shade on sunny days.
meanings.sent2: The leafed branches swayed gently in the breeze, creating a soothing rustling sound.
meanings.sent3: The leafed plants in the garden seemed to be whispering secrets to each other.
meanings.sent4: The forest was a sea of green, with leafed trees reaching towards the sky.
meanings.sent5: The leafed vines climbed up the wall, adding a touch of nature to the room.

meanings.definition: (noun) a single sheet of paper in a book or document
meanings.sent1: She found a note on the leafed of her diary, reminding her of an important appointment.
meanings.sent2: The leafed of the contract contained the terms and conditions of the agreement.
meanings.sent3: He scribbled a quick message on the leafed of the notepad before rushing out.
meanings.sent4: The leafed of the menu listed the chef's specials for the day.
meanings.sent5: The leafed of the letter was neatly folded inside the envelope.
